author: UnplayableConundrum
body: ah its all good man, profit is profit. Gains are Gains. I think that we gotta be cognizant of that fact. Being greedy or chasing stuff is what makes people lose it all. We now know the outcome so its easy to say "I could have made so much more" but there are another infinite outcomes where I could have lost money too.

author: Bored_At_Work727
body: I bought AAPL back in March. With the split, I now own 12.x pieces of fruit, and I'm up 75% since I purchased. I feel as if I would be smart to take my winnings, and then move them to a smaller priced item that has some short term growth. I tend to spend my money on mutual funds, but I am trying to churn my initial $6k investment this year into something more substantial to play with, while being cognizant of the tax implications from making too many short term buy/sells. Looking for a little advice. I've got money in some of the more common/"good" ones like MSFT, FB, F, AMZN, KO, SBUX, etc. but seeking out something different...

author: Dontreadgud
body:
I think that's quite an assumption, but you did call yourself a sheep so maybe.  

Personally, to me even short term games are under the "investing" umbrella.  I'm not a day trader, I have a job.  However I did buy into Disney before Disney plus and made $30 a share, there are other examples of both wins and losses.  But I still have long term positions with AMD and TMUS.  I'm on the fence about my solar stocks and a bit leary as a good portion is sitting there turning too much profit too quick...I have to be cognizant of the day to day which I don't like stressing over.   Then I have my short positions like GE....I bought in around 6.5 and am watching it run circles on its way up to $10.

author: Okmanl
body:
Apple during a large period of its history. And also Tesla from 2014-2020. 

People were cognizant of the amazing growth of both companies. People waited 20+ years for Apple stock to finally blow up. Some people even died waiting. Another example is that Tesla was projected to double in size every 3-4 years. Where they built a gigafactory. And then 2 gigafactories and then 4. And then each factory was constructed in such a way that it could triple in size if need be. 

Yet Tesla’s stock price remained stagnant from 2014-2020.

EQNR. Those offshore wind turbines in the picture, thats Equinor’s design. Alot of the oil majors are going to switch to renewables, but equinor especially since they are much more subject to the will of the state than any of the others. Norway is very cognizant of its precarious reliance on fossil fuels.
And EQNR, like the other oils stocks is super beat up

author: PrimeOrigin
body: No - Amazon has enough lobbyists and 'non' lobbyists that it'll never happen. Legally the company has been very cognizant of this and has a decent posture in place. While the effects of Amazon and the 'growth for growth's sake' strategy beg a lot of theoretical/ethical questions they are very good about maintaining the litmus test of antitrust, i.e. consumer welfare is better because we actively bring them lower prices and better value. As long as they can channel that message they're all set.

author: thrifty_prole
body:
If you are just looking for extended hours execution, check out WeBull. If you are looking for that plus a more robust interface, either TDAmeritrade’s thinkorswim or Interactive Brokers’ Trader Workstation.

A good thing to be cognizant of is that you get what you pay for: RH makes $$$ by sending your orders to be frontrun by HFT firms. The other brokers will offer you choice of execution (e.g., place your order on IEX and not BATS) and that nuance will save you $$$ and get you and your trade where you want it to be.

author: thewimsey
body:
No, it's not sketchy because money is involved.

The key to Bill Gates being successful wasn't that his mother knew some guy at IBM; it was that his wealthy family sent him to an expensive private school where he both met Paul Allen *and* learned about computers.  Gates's mom served on a charitable board with the CEO of IBM; they were more associates than friends, and that wouldn't have helped Gates at all if he hadn't already, you know, founded MS. 

Elon's family didn't own an emerald mine, and he was $100k in debt when he graduated college. 

Meritocracy just means that merit - mostly in the sense of skills - is rewarded. It doesn't mean that everyone necessarily has an equal chance. 

If a company needs and engineer and I have an engineering degree, and you don't - maybe because you had an abusive family growing up wit a father in prison and so never graduated from HS, the company is hiring me *on merit*. I'm an engineer; you're not; you can't do the job. 

This doesn't mean that if our lives were switched at age 3 I would have done any better; that's just a separate question from meritocracy. 

I mean, if a company needs someone who speaks French, and my wealthy family summered in France every year and sent me there one a gap year and then on a junior year abroad...while you took French in HS...merit means I get the job *even though* I was only able to obtain my qualifications because my family was rich enough to keep sending me to France. 

But the company isn't hiring me because of who I am, but because of what I can do, and that I can do it better than you can.

author: LucisMensEtManus
body:
You have a number of comments on your financial model, so I won't comment there.

To me, what is missing is the story. First, comparison to the Leidos, CACI, BAH, IBM, HPE etc. of the government consulting world. They too employ a lot of talent. What is the difference with PLTR? Second, government consulting is often a "customer intimate" model, not quality leadership. Govt says it wants high tech, but they often buy those companies who understand them most. Which model is PLTR using? Why will PLTR succeed in Govt? Is it primarily IC?

Third, if PLTR has silicon valley magic in it, then why is the commercial business not taking off? If you have a superior value proposition, that will be reflected in high margins and a kind of inevitability of customers who are drawn to your products. A weakness there would make me pause.

author: 3000dollarsuitCOMEON
body:
Competition, brand deterioration, and forced breakups by government action. 

No company is invulnerable given time. Standard Oil in the early 1900s, IBM when mainframes were everything. Capital is so cheap right now that it's easy for startups to get funds. It may not seem like it but consumers will switch for better products or ways of doing things. Brands don't last forever and companies become more and more difficult to manage as their size increases.

Also don't forget the world is much bigger than just the US. China and other large developed countries are full of brilliant people, lots of access to capital. How long until Alibaba has boots on the ground in USA and starts aggressively pressuring Amazon?

My guess is that eventually the government will put a stop to big tech simply buying out their competitors. It's already a bipartisan talking point.

author: audion00ba
body:
I can't even say whether this is sarcasm or not. You mean the IBM Power10 processor? 

The only thing that's sort of interesting is the "Distributed Memory Disaggregation and Sharing"-feature, but that processor is not available until the end of 2021. If there is any proof that it is *real* and is competitive in terms of pricing, then I might see some value there. 

The world has been moving to commodity servers for the past 15 years. IBM is everything but that. 

IBM has a debt of 50B. I don't see how their current assets are worth more than their debt.

author: diesel408
body: So the other response summed it up pretty well, but left one other important factor out. The importance of Intel's architecture is fading. It will always be around of course, but anyone that doesn't think ARM is going to keep getting a larger and larger bite of the pie isn't paying attention. Apple will give everyone permission to target software for ARM architecture and we'll soon see a second attempt from Microsoft. Again, we'll always have applications for Intel, but it won't be nearly as dominant. Intel's production woes over the past half decade are well documented, and it's clear that they are about as well run as Boeing these days. The problem for Intel is that they face much more fierce competition than Boeing. Intel will survive of course, but they'll be a shell of their former self, and they'll have fumbled their flagship products and missed the boat on the areas of the industry that are sure to see rapid growth. I understand that people want to target value, but Intel is priced the way they are for good reason. If you're looking for value in Intel then I have some IBM stock to sell you as well.

body:
They have small competitors here and there, mostly small scale startups. Closest ones worth mentioning that I can think of and are not mainstream companies like IBM are companies like Leidos and Booz Allen Hamilton.

The way their business model works is fundamentally different from Palantir. They evaluate technologies and purchase/ contracts from smaller companies (maybe startups) and package it up as a complete solution and sell it to the government. This essentially means that these companies are a little more than resellers of tech. Palantir's direct to consumer model focus their investments in RnD.

**Spce** is legit. Keep in mind that is a rocket science company. Suppose gov't did not give the clearance for 2 years we understand they are ready can wait for 2 years.  So I will be around so long there are investors willing to keep the company running.

As for the eV controversial giant, this is not quite finished. Personally even if they have no product or schedule they will linger around awhile. They can use their patents sue every manufacturer in eV and often they generate revenue from those manufacturers as hush up money.

Some years ago, a hard disk manufacturer making 3.5" hard drive business was failing. It had a strong intellectual property department sued every hard disk manufacturer in the 3.5" drive claiming patient infringement. In 1990 IBM was hit with a lawsuit as an inventor of the drive and sue by a smaller player. It paid some hush money. Seagate was dismissed in 1997, sue again and paid [$45 M to R+ as late as 2000](https://www.electronicsweekly.com/news/archived/resources-archived/seagate-to-pay-rodime-45m-to-settle-suit-2000-01/).   R+ only exists as a shell company and its share price soared on news of the patent settlement.  I think **NKLA** can remain as a shell company with its patent portfolio covering designs that covers most vehicles built electric or not. [It sue Tsla earlier](https://www.forbes.com/sites/alanohnsman/2020/04/20/teslas-effort-to-short-circuit-nikola-lawsuit-fizzles-as-patent-office-denies-door-argument/?sh=44dc21a45d78). author: thewimsey
body:
MSFT wasn't  a computer company. It was a software company. IBM was a computer company.

The brilliance of MSFT was in - and this seems weird today - realizing that a company could make money just selling software. A ton of money. More money than computer makers could make by themselves. This was a kind of radical idea at the time.

Jobs was very successful at the computer business; the Apple was the bestselling PC from 1977-1982.

Apple wasn't killed by MSFT, it was killed by IBM, which built a PC from more or less off the shelf parts allowing *anyone* to build a clone. (Which, incidentally, would run windows). 

Apple's computers couldn't compete with PCs built with off the shelf parts. It's not about Jobs being bad; it's about other people being better.

IBM's approach almost immediately priced *them* out of the PC market, leaving the profits to MSFT and intel (and a tiny bit for clone makers, who mostly ended up in a low margin commodity business).

author: DarkStarOptions
body:
>It does limit your loss by a half, but it does increase your probability of loss by a factor of two as well. Now that you close the spread once it gets touched, your probability of loss is now the probability of touching the short strike (which is approximately twice the probability of being ITM).

As opposed to waiting to see if the stock rebounds off the short strike?  

Makes sense.

&#x200B;

I opened a spread against IBM about 3 weeks ago, a 35 day spread.  It initially dipped below the short strike but I didn't freak out because I had 30 days for it to go back up....and it did.  Now my spread is OTM and profitable and has been for about a week.  

&#x200B;

This guy was putting forth a strategy of writing a spread with a short strike of 20 delta for < 14 days.  I guess the thought is if the stock moved that much in a short amount of time to test the short strike, probably best to just close it for a loss rather than manage it with just a few days left until expiration.  That's my guess but I don't know because I didn't ask him.

author: skilliard7
body:
> Bitcoin has plenty of intrinsic use. These include borderless transfer without needing to convert to to local currency (cant do this with Western Union), black markets, safe haven from oppressive governments, sending aid to citizens of oppressive governments, ways to bypass import sanctions (see Iran), and more. Just because you don't have intrinsic use for BTC, doesn't mean others don't (see link below).

You can do this with Ethereum, Litecoin, Monero, Vertcoin, even Dogecoin. I agree cryptocurrency and blockchains are useful but I don't see Bitcoin as a long term store of value. It's far more volatile than precious metals and also intangible.

IBM is making huge strides towards quantum computing, and once they pull it off, Bitcoin will become worthless once the public/private key cryptography is cracked and anyone with access to a quantum computer can simply sign transactions to send coins to themselves. We're easily within 10 years at this point, possibly less.

>This is like saying anyone can create a better social network than Facebook and therefore Facebook has no value

What about Myspace? It came first.

>Wrong. Best case scenario is that BTC continues to be added to the balance sheets of large, publicly traded companies

Like 1 or 2 companies that hold it as a tiny position. I think Overstock and Square? Most companies that accept it just use Bitpay or Coinbase to instantly sell it.

author: WrongWeekToQuit
body:
I still see the comparisons...

You had outright fraud from Enron, Worldcom, etc... not unlike Lickin, Wirecard, Nikola.

You had companies with high valuations that confounded the people who tried to value them like Amazon.  The same things being said of Tesla were said about Amazon back then.

You had tech darlings like Microsoft, Cisco, Oracle, Intel, etc... that ran up huge amounts, making employees into millionaires.

You had highly anticipated IPOs of companies, some very immature like pets.com, but some big like doubleclick, etc... If you look at Big Commerce's or Lemonade's financials, they aren't great. I agree that there was more vaporware back in the late 90s, BUT, the fervor, the blind investing into companies without knowing anything about their financials, the double or triple digit gains within a single year.... remind you of any recent times?

author: ezekiel1525
body:
Hey there,I've done an extreme amount of research about AMD and have been actively trading them for about 3 years now, so it is a quite large portion of my portfolio at the moment and it's a stock that I always advocate family & friends to purchase as well. I definitely wouldn't advise you to put all your eggs in one basket, but I do believe that AMD is a very good buy in the long-term.

Fundamentally, they have an absurdly phenomenal management team. Since Lisa Su's inception, the company has experienced tremendous growth and even managed to steal away Intel's lead architect. Although AMD has always has great products, Lisa Su has really managed to take it to the next level and make AMD nearly a household name at this point with the rise of customized computer building.

I guess to answer your question better, if you're planning on holding this for 10+ years, I have no doubts that this stock will grow especially with its acquisition of Xilinx and incredible product line. These synergies match especially well and I don't see a way that Intel could possibly topple AMD as it previously has. The semiconductor industry has been seeing a growing prevalence, especially with its intertwining of AI (i.e. NVDIA).  


EDIT: I know that might be a pretty ambiguous answer, but I've done a few analyses and reports on AMD, so if you have any other questions regarding their financials/future outlook, feel free to reach out!

author: moldyjellybean
body:
The datacenter business can't migrate that quickly. Even for us who started to try amd in 2017, but only in test environment at that time.  Been burned by the Opteron garbage AMD put out many year ago.  We still have entire wings of a datacenter running all Intel. The electricity in one portion of the colocation runs us tens of thousands.   

It's in multiple colocations across the US to provide high availability, we have to rent out space from places like Equinix datacenters.  

Moving to AMD in certain colocations has allowed us to host the same number of virtual machines while using 1/2 the footprint, at about 60%-70% of the power costs.  Not only are we saving space at the datacenter but we're saving a ton in power costs.  I can't imagine how much space, power, and cooling a major player with billions or cores is saving.

author: CallidusVulpes
body:
Nice, glad I could help. I'm good at the most important parts of investing (evaluating companies), but bad at a lot of the nuances, so there are a lot of tools I don't even know how to use effectively. 

QQQ looks very good I might get some when I want to stop monitoring the stock market like a mad man.

Incoming rant on why AMD is good (it will go into the specifics of why AMD is going to be very competitive in the GPU and CPU markets). This will get fairly technical, but I tried to keep it understandable just in case you aren't as nerdy as me lol. There is a lot of info though, but I feel like I made it less frantic. I'll understand if you don't read it all or still choose not to invest in AMD, talking about tech is a hobby of mine.

I could go on for a very long time why AMD is a really good play SPOILER ALERT: I'm about to :). [I mean really all you need to know is that Intel is very far behind (at least the consumer thinks that, but in reality Intel is still even with AMD, but barely)]. In June 2018 AMD had 8% of the consumer CPU market and by November 2019 they had 20% and by the end of Q3 2020 they had 37.3%. They are carving a massive hole in the market. AMD's new GPUs combat NVidias [at least that's what their marketing says, but AMD's marketing has been very good since Lisa Su became the CEO/COO, she is an actual electrical engineer and has been essential in bringing AMD back from the brink of bankruptcy in 2017 (AMD was expected to go bankrupt in 2018 if they didn't release something)]. 

I know it can be difficult to trust some random person on the internet, so you should look at the news. All tech news indicates that AMD is going to be doing very well this quarter and it seems like NVidia knows this as well, since they coincidentally delayed their 3070 GPUs 2 weeks ahead, so that it was literally the day before AMD's Big Navi announcement. Intel won't have a response to AMD's 5000 series (which is releasing this month) until early 2021 and those CPUs will be practically equal (probably slightly better) to the 5000 series, but probably cost more. The crux of Intel's problem is Intel's aging 14nm process, AMD is using TSMC's 7nm process (and is designing its next CPUs around TSMC's 5nm process). The difference between the 14nm process and the 7nm process is transistor density TSMC has a transistor density of 90 MT/mm² (million transistors per square millimeter) while Intel's is much worse (no exact figures because Intel doesn't share that). The reason we can tell it's worse is because Intel's CPUs run much hotter than AMD's, yet have similar performance (people don't gravitate to Intel due to Intel's poor pricing) which means that Intel is having to push more power through the CPU to reach comparable speeds (which produces the extra heat). 

Back to GPUs, the 3090 (1500 USD) is NVidia's top-end flagship ridiculously priced card (NVidia and most other tech companies have one usually you pay double the price of the product below it while only gaining a negligible 15% performance boost) and the 6900XT (1000 USD) costs 500 less while delivering the same performance (when I say the same I mean in some games/workloads the 3090 wins and in others the 6900XT and it's always by a negligible margin). The 3080 is the reasonable 700 USD GPU (it's actually a very good value, especially when compared to NVidia's last gen pricing) but AMD has an answer to that too, and it's the 6800XT which also has very similar performance and costs 50 USD less, and I haven't even gotten to the best part: NVidia completely sold out of all of their GPUs within minutes and do not have ANY in stock rn and a lot of gamers want these new GPUs since they are such a massive leap forward, to put it in perspective the 3080 costs 100 USD less than the 2080 ti as of rn (the 2080 ti was the most expensive card from NVidia's last lineup) and has 33% more performance, gamers will buy whatever is available, plus NVidia had a shitty launch for a great product (they sold a lot of cards to scalpers and allowed them to buy multiple cards because they didn't add recaptcha or anything like that and their supply was already limited due to their choice to use faster (and lower yield) GDDR6X memory over just normal GDDR6 (AMD uses regular GDDR6, but they make up the performance by using TSMC's 7nm which is much denser than Samsung's 8nm the names of processes are not really indicative of transistor density), so people are angry). The cards that most people will buy are lower down the stack, but time and time again it has became evident that even if someone will ultimately buy a mid-tier GPU if the company that makes the mid-tier GPU isn't competitive on the high-end then they will purchase the mid-level GPU from the company that is competitive on the high-end (this hurt AMD bad last gen with GPUs) so that is why I won't go over the mid-low end as much (it is worth noting that AMD does have much better GPUs on the mid-low end)

author: diesel408
body: So the other response summed it up pretty well, but left one other important factor out. The importance of Intel's architecture is fading. It will always be around of course, but anyone that doesn't think ARM is going to keep getting a larger and larger bite of the pie isn't paying attention. Apple will give everyone permission to target software for ARM architecture and we'll soon see a second attempt from Microsoft. Again, we'll always have applications for Intel, but it won't be nearly as dominant. Intel's production woes over the past half decade are well documented, and it's clear that they are about as well run as Boeing these days. The problem for Intel is that they face much more fierce competition than Boeing. Intel will survive of course, but they'll be a shell of their former self, and they'll have fumbled their flagship products and missed the boat on the areas of the industry that are sure to see rapid growth. I understand that people want to target value, but Intel is priced the way they are for good reason. If you're looking for value in Intel then I have some IBM stock to sell you as well.

body:
No you're right this is all hand waving and speculation. What I believe is that Intel isn't leading in servers and they aren't leading in mobile. Like it or not, that's where the growth is. Sure their business is solid but in truth they really aren't worth much more than their dividend. There's a place in every portfolio for dividends, but personally I don't look to the tech sector for dividends. Things move too quickly and you don't have the same kind of stranglehold on markets as you do in other industries. If I want dividends I'm looking at financials or REITs or energy. But hey, that's a personal preference.

Intel is a fine company, but there's so many slam dunks in tech right now that why would you lock up some of your capital in INTC?

author: CallidusVulpes
body: Nvidia is a safe investment in the long run (they might go down a bit this month though due to AMD, but overall Nvidia has went up consistently over the past 5 years and has shown no signs of deviating significantly from that), Microsoft is safe, Tesla is too scary for me personally. I don't buy ETFs or evaluate them, I evaluate individual stocks then choose whether or not I would like to purchase them. I play for large short term gains (large relative to my investment portfolio and short meaning a few months typically). I've made a 17.49% profit in the past 2 weeks (starting with 2k) due to making "all in" bets on Corsair (to be clear to do this I was incredibly confident it was going to go up, but I definitely wouldn't advise it if you do not need the money, I have a stupidly low retirement target). Corsair was likely my most risky investment that's why I left quickly. AMD and TSMC are great investments for a couple of years, probably 3 years or more (TSMC almost definitely 3 years or more since they make the most powerful CPUs that go in the new Xbox, PS5, AMD CPUs, Apple CPUs, and they even have Intel waiting in line since their factories are all in use). You'll almost definitely hate my diversity, but I'm likely going to buy all AMD and TSMC (In my opinion diversity is for people who don't know much about the market they are invested in or don't feel like keeping up with the news). If I were to make a more long-term safer account I'd buy NVidia, Apple, AMD, and TSMC (Diversification in different sectors doesn't help if the entire market goes down, and I don't believe these specific tech stocks have exited a year down for the past decade (I know at least for the past 5 years they haven't), except for AMD which completely changed as a company). I'm putting all of my money on AMD and TSMC once the market opens tomorrow (I'd recommend stocking up ASAP on those stocks since they had a bad day on Friday). Apple will likely not see that much growth if any this quarter, but they'll be great for the long term. If you don't have the stomach or patience for seeing temporary losses then I would not recommend tech (Microsoft isn't too bad actually). I've sat on 200 USD losses (which is 10% of my portfolio) and went positive 145 USD the next day (that was my worst timed trade with Corsair). This probably looks very frantic, sorry, I'm a bit too excited.

body: I agree, also there is so much correlation these days due to everyone buying passive funds, that stocks such as Amazon follow the broad market anyway. The only difference is they have what I call a fundemental multiplier, whereas in news for that company will make it swing bigger one way or the other. For some this adds incredible risk, look at intel for example. But amzn itself is already internally diversified and so far more robust.

author: veilwalker
body: That is the point. INTC is priced as though it won't figure it out. INTC looks like a better buy at this point as the market is really down on them right now.

author: alles_long
body:
I think we differ in the understanding of the relationship between intel and AMD. 

I agree with your last point though, that is why I have been holding shares and LT warrants..

author: Raus_1
body:
The sentiment about INTC is that they are dinosaur that will inevitably loose it's market share. But Intel doesn't only produce CPUs, their portfolio is much bigger. And **I think**, that Intel will be back in 5 years. It will take them some time, but the fact that they don't make only CPUs will help them. And when the sentiment is negative, it might be great opportunity to buy, and collect some dividends in the meanwhile. I'm contrarian here.

AMD at this point still might be great growth opportunity, you could make big gains, or loose it, depends on what the market will do

author: ShaidarHaran2
body: Bulldozer was a terrible diversion, their integration of ATI took many years for both to recover and bear fruit. Hindsight 20/20. When Zen was detailed and released, that's when there was more reason to see that they'd be coming close to Intel like IPC and would be harder to shake off from there with convergent architectures.

author: 123shipping
body: Intel just needs to fire their ceo and it's a upward trending catalyst.

author: j455b
body: INTC Put depends on it. Its my 75$ lotto scratcher that is supposed o track the market!

author: Raus_1
body:
The market is cyclical, once you are on top, few years later you are losing. Intel will go lover, but they are one good product away from being back.

The fact, that they don't have anything competitive right now doesn't mean they will let themselves die. I don't remember it personally, but Intel and AMD both had their highs and lows.

https://www.zunesis.com/a-history-of-the-semiconductor-market-amd-vs-intel/

I might sound like Intel fanboy, but I have Ryzen in my PC, and will buy another. I'm celebrating competition, not the company.

author: zhexiangxd
body: Valuation wise Intel is cheap, but stocks is all about the future. For value investing, I rather buy companies like Disney that has a sure chance to recover than betting on Intel to come back in the future.

author: beamsplosion
body:
Because, when AMD wasn’t competition for Intel anymore, they gave us +5%/generation for 6 years. Now that AMD is a threat, Intel’s suddenly trying again. I won’t stand by a company that cares more about money than innovation. 

By the way, look up a benchmark comparison between Intel’s current flagship and their last gen (10900K vs 9900K), it speaks volumes about how Intel is.

author: kenyard
body:
The issue to me is that pe of 10 takes 10 years to recoup or double your money assuming it continues to produce like that.    
Intel decreasing revenue makes me think it will be much longer than this.     
Amd currently will take 100 years as you rightly say. Their revenues are increasing 30% and more year on year so it will be much much shorter.    
They are taking the server market share which are high margin areas. They are making a reliable name for themselves. They are able to charge more of a premium now.

author: InfiniteValueptr
body:
As I said already, by responding to 

> TSMC and Samsung lead the market. The US based foundries, Intel and   GlobalFoundries, are 2 and 1 generations behind respectively. 

with 

>  The foundries of TSMC and Samsung are US technology made with US IP, licenced to TSMC and Samsung by American companies.   
>  
> They wouldn’t be able to do the and require TSMC to apply for a US   licence to sell to an entity list Chinese company if the foundries were   not US technology. 

you clearly said that TSMC licenses foundry technology from the US. As I'm sure a supremely intelligent being such as yourself can understand, you can't license and mass produce fabrication processes that don't exist. Therefore, the only logical conclusion that can be drawn from your statement of TSMC and Samsung licensing US fabrication technology is that US fabrication technology is superior to theirs.

author: griswalt7
body: Even more reason to watch. Too bad I can’t play $INTC and $AMD because of my job.

author: MGT01
body: Seems like Intel got lazy as a company and is riding the same old shit year after year. Result is no growth. The stock market likes growth.

author: dareftw
body:
It’s pretty true. I have a BS in Economics and an MA in applied economics and an MQM (Masters in Quantitative Management) as well. And the first question people ask when they find out what I did in college is about the economy and stocks. And it’s a dumb question and they don’t even realize it. Like I spent years learning about scarcity and a bunch of basically applied calculus and statistics. 

Unless I work directly for a brokerage I wouldn’t have enough time to make an informed decision any one way or the other, and even then it would only be a best estimate and one with enough of a likely chance to not be correct that it would be pretty irresponsible to give an opinion on it. 

I can fully do the math behind it sure, but the stock market has proven time and time again that it’s irrational and not really predictable with any algorithm. There is a reason that economic theory even says throwing a dart at a chart of stocks and picking where it lands is just as likely to be accurate than if you picked it based on extensive amounts of DD and research. 

But I just point people towards index’s, tell them if they aren’t retiring in the next 5 years don’t be afraid or worried that the stock market drops every now and then etc etc. 

tl;dr Economists don’t study the economy they study scarcity. I’d be extremely skeptical of any economist claiming to know what the market will do or that they have figured out the stock market. We exist to do small scale data analysis, or to advise large scale economic moves aka monetary/fiscal policy, we aren’t adept at guessing small movements within certain markets. And if we’re in a spot where we can then we are also in a spot where the sec would have something to say if we profited off it.

More than 50% of the companies currently listed will likely go to zero in your lifetime. Saying Amazon can't fail likely means there are other investors that share your same attitude, not only is that incorrect but it is priced in. You can draw the same conclusion throughout history with companies like exxon, general electric, ma bell, how could they lose and they did.

Also, Amazon is great i own a lot. I did make a weighted bet and I do agree no more than 10% per company.

author: ace425
body: Knowing the Chinese, they'll find a way to seize the company and have him replaced with someone willing to toe the party line instead of outright destroying the company. If they outright fucked over one of the single largest Chinese companies in existence it would destroy international trust and investment in Chinese firms for a long time to come. They aren't that stupid. They'll find a way to make Ma bend to their will, or they'll hand the company over to someone else. Then the IPO will move forward.
